item.title: Terence add a quote by Neil Simon
item.description: "When its 100 degrees in New York, it's 72 in Los Angeles. When its 30 degrees in New York, in Los Angeles it's still 72. However, there are 6 million interesting people in New York, and only 72 in Los Angeles." -- Neil Simon

item.title: Terence add a quote by E.B. White
item.description: "New York is to the nation what the white church spire is to the village - the visible symbol of aspiration and faith, the white plume saying the way is up" -- E.B. White

item.title: Terence add a quote by John Steinbeck
item.description: "Once you have lived in New York and made it your home, no place else is good enough" -- John Steinbeck

item.title: Terence add a quote by Kurt Vonnegut
item.description: "...Skyscraper National Park" -- Kurt Vonnegut

item.title: Terence add a quote by F. Scott Fitzgerald
item.description: "New York had all the iridescence of the beginning of the world." -- F. Scott Fitzgerald

item.title: Terence add a quote by Arthur C. Clarke
item.description: "If man can live in Manhattan, he can live anywhere." -- Arthur C. Clarke

item.title: Terence add a quote by O. Henry
item.description: "It couldn't have happened anywhere but in little old New York." -- O. Henry

item.title: Terence add a quote by Walt Whitman
item.description: "This is the city, and I am one of the citizens/Whatever interests the rest interests me" -- Walt Whitman

item.title: Terence add a quote by Fran Lebowitz
item.description: "When you leave New York, you are astonished at how clean the rest of the world is. Clean is not enough." -- Fran Lebowitz

item.title: Terence add a quote by David Sedaris
item.description: "It was generally agreed that a coffin-size studio on Avenue D was preferable to living in one of the boroughs. Moving from one Brooklyn or Staten Island neighborhood to another was fine, but unless you had children to think about, even the homeless saw it as a step down to leave Manhattan. Customers quitting the island for Astoria or Cobble Hill would claim to welcome the change of pace, saying it would be nice to finally have a garden or live a little closer to the airport. Theyâ€™d put a good face one it, but one could always detect an underlying sense of defeat. The apartments might be bigger and cheaper in other places, but one could never count on their old circle of friend making the long trip to attend a birthday party. Even Washington Heights was considered a stretch. People referred to it as Upstate New York, though it was right there in Manhattan." -- David Sedaris

item.title: Terence add a quote by Woody Allen
Terence add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "I would give the greatest sunset in the world for one sight of New York's skyline. Particularly when one can't see the details. Just the shapes. The shapes and the thought that made them. The sky over New York and the will of man made visible. What other religion do we need? And then people tell me about pilgrimages to some dank pesthole in a jungle where they go to do homage to a crumbling temple, to a leering stone monster with a pot belly, created by some leprous savage. Is it beauty and genius they want to see? Do they seek a sense of the sublime? Let them come to New York, stand on the shore of the Hudson, look and kneel. When I see the city from my window - no, I don't feel how small I am - but I feel that if a war came to threaten this, I would throw myself into space, over the city, and protect these buildings with my body." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: Terence add a quote by Truman Capote
item.description: "I love New York, even though it isn't mine, the way something has to be, a tree or a street or a house, something, anyway, that belongs to me because I belong to it." -- Truman Capote

item.title: Terence add a quote by Woody Allen
item.description: "There is no question that there is an unseen world. The problem is, how far is it from midtown and how late is it open?" -- Woody Allen

item.title: Terence add a quote by Tom Wolfe
item.description: "One belongs to New York instantly, one belongs to it as much in five minutes as in five years." -- Tom Wolfe

item.title: Terence add a quote by George Carlin
item.description: "Of course, in Los Angeles, <I>everything</i> is based on driving, even the killings. In New York, most people don't have cars, so if you want to kill a person, you have to take the subway to their house. And sometimes on the way, the train is delayed and you get impatient, so you have to kill someone on the subway. That's why there are so many subway murders; no one has a car." -- George Carlin

item.title: Terence add a quote by Lindsey Kelk
item.description: "People go to LA to "find themselves", they come to New York to become someone new." -- Lindsey Kelk

item.title: Terence add a quote by F. Scott Fitzgerald
item.description: "The city seen from the Queensboro Bridge is always the city seen for the first time, in its first wild promise of all the mystery and the beauty in the world." -- F. Scott Fitzgerald

item.title: Terence add a quote by John Updike
item.description: "The true New Yorker secretly believes that people living anywhere else have to be, in some sense, kidding." -- John Updike

item.title: Terence add a quote by Helen Keller
item.description: "Cut off as I am, it is inevitable that I should sometimes feel like a shadow walking in a shadowy world. When this happens I ask to be taken to New York City. Always I return home weary but I have the comforting certainty that mankind is real flesh and I myself am not a dream." -- Helen Keller

item.title: Terence add a quote by Kurt Vonnegut
item.description: "So I went to New York City to be born again. It was and remains easy for most Americans to go somewhere else and start anew. I wasn't like my parents. I didn't have any supposedly sacred piece of land or shoals of friends to leave behind. Nowhere has the number zero been of more philisophical value than in the United States.... and when the [train] plunged into a tunnel under New York City, with it's lining of pipes and wires, I was out of the womb and into the birth canal." -- Kurt Vonnegut
